column2: Full Name
column18: Course Outcomes: all

column1: PHARM 327 (Winter 2016 LEC B1 B2 SEM J1)
column2: PHARM 327 Wi16 - NUTRITION Combined LEC SEM Wi16
column7: Healthy Diet, Canadian Health Food Guide
column18: By the end of this course, students will be able to know and understand nutritional terminology, what a healthy diet is, macro/micro nutrient requirements, and the role of nutrients in health and disease states (obesity, diabetes, cardiovascular, osteoporosis, gut diseases, cancer, autoimmune-inflammatory diseases, and metabolic syndrome).
column19: By the time students finish the course, they should be able to explain their learning and knowledge in the area of nutrition to others. This will be tested by multiple choices and short-answer exam questions.
column20: By the end of this course, students will be able to develop an appreciation of the fundamental importance of nutrition.

column1: PHARM 327 (Winter 2016 LEC B1 B2 SEM J1)
column2: PHARM 327 Wi16 - NUTRITION Combined LEC SEM Wi16
PHARM 497 ENDOCRINE (LEC B1 Wi16)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column18: Explain the pharmacologic effects of drugs used in the management of endocrine disorders.
column19: Describe the specific laboratory tests used in the diagnosis and monitoring of endocrine disorders.
column20: Describe the therapeutic approach incorporating non-pharmacologic and pharmacologic treatments to the prevention, treatment and management of endocrine disorders, including use of specific target drugs for condition as well as alternative therapies (dose, route of administration, length of therapy, monitoring parameters).
column21: Recognize and understand the appropriate acute management strategies for patients with diabetes, including travel, exercise and acute illness.
column22: Describe the toxicity of medications used in the management of endocrine disorders.
column23: Identify the role and the responsibility of the pharmacist within the course of the disease state and its therapy.
column24: Identify applicable health system resources.
column25: Identify and resolve clinically significant drug interactions.
column26: Select appropriate treatment for special groups (e.g., pediatrics, geriatrics, pregnant or lactating women).
column27: Apply concepts and knowledge of medicinal chemistry, pharmacology, and therapeutic principles for pharmacologic management of endocrine disorders.
column28: Identify actual and potential drug-related problems associated with pharmacologic management of endocrine disorders.
column29: Develop a patient care plan related to the care of patients with endocrine disorders, including appropriate monitoring and documentation.
column30: Identify when to inform physicians and caregivers if there are danger signs apparent in the assessment.
column31: Identify and retrieve appropriate sources of information needed to resolve drug related problems.
column32: Use the principles of evidence-based medicine to critically evaluate the validity and applicability of information from various literature resources.
column33: Accept responsibility for keeping abreast of emerging technologies and drugs.

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa16)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column16: INTRODUCTION / RADIATION PRINCIPLES: Brief overview of what to expect from this course; Begin content of next lecture

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa16)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column16: RADIATION PRINCIPLES: Atomic structure; concepts of nuclear stability; radioactive isotopes; radiation emissions;Types of radioactive decay associated with nuclides commonly used for medical purposes.

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa16)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa16)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column16: RADIATION EFFECTS ON LIVING SYSTEMS; Units of radioactivity; calculations involving radioactive decay, calculations for radiopharmaceutical dosage to allow for radioactive decay; concepts of physical, biological and effective half-life; Charged particles; electromagnetic radiation, thermal and fast neurons, physical characteristics, sources, interactions with matter, energy loss, tissue penetration (this topic presented from a health sciences viewpoint)

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa16)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column16: RADIATION EFFECTS ON LIVING SYSTEMS: Concepts of radiation energy in terms of transfer and absorption in biological systems; Mechanisms of radiation induced injury; Oxidative stress as a result of radiation, and biological effects; Antioxidant enzymes as deterrents to free radical induced damage.

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa16)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column16: RADIATION EFFECTS ON LIVING SYSTEMS: Other radicals that can partake in radiation induced damage; Damage of free radicals to biological targets and its consequences; Free radicals and cell death; A description of the enzymatic and nonenzymatic systems to detoxify radiation induced free radical formation; Free radicals and cell death; Signalling mechanisms that can result in death or carcinogenesis

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa16)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column16: MIDTERM EXAM, MCQs based on material covered in week 1 - 3.

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa16)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column16: RADIOSENSITIZATION AND PHOTOSENSITIZATION: Concepts and therapeutic advantage to combining radiation with pharmaceuticals; Mechanisms of radiation therapy and chemotherapy; The role of free radicals in mediating chemotherapeutic/toxic action; Chemical requirements for radiosensitizers; Radioprotection as a means to prevent damage to normal tissues; Photosensitization as a means to generate reactive species for photodynamic therapy

column2: PHARM 367 Wi16 - CARDIOLOGY Combined LEC Wi16
column18: Describe medicinal chemistry, pharmacology and therapeutic principles applicable to selecting and monitoring drug therapy for the management of the conditions of primary focus.
column19: Describe pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic principles applicable to the treatment of the conditions of primary focus.
column20: Explain the effects of drugs used in the management of the conditions of primary focus.
column21: Describe the specific laboratory tests used in the diagnosis and monitoring of the conditions of primary focus
column22: Describe the therapeutic approach incorporating non-pharmacologic and pharmacologic treatments of the conditions of primary focus including use of specific target drugs for condition as well as alternative therapies (dose, route of administration, length of therapy, monitoring parameters)
column23: Describe how to manage the toxicity of cardiac medications
column24: Describe the societal and economic impact of the conditions of primary focus
column25: Identify ethical issues surrounding treatment of the conditions of primary focus
column26: Identify the role and the responsibility of the pharmacist within the course of the disease state and its therapy.
column27: Identify applicable health system resources
column28: Obtain a relevant history from a patient
column29: Review the presenting signs and symptoms of the conditions of primary focus and describe criteria used to make the diagnosis and to be able to relate the severity of the disease
column30: Discuss the therapeutic options with patient, including risks and benefits, and medication and alternative therapy choices
column31: Apply and demonstrate appropriate counseling and communication with patients
column32: Follow appropriate monitoring parameters
column33: Recommend appropriate changes to therapy based on patient outcomes and monitoring parameters
column34: Design pharmaceutical care plans including alternatives (drug, non-drug, referral, reassurance), recommendations, implementation, monitoring and follow up for patients with the conditions of primary focus.
column35: Identify actual and potential drug related problems relating the conditions of primary focus and in various patient cases.
column36: Manage clinically significant drug interactions with drugs used to treat the conditions of primary focus.
column37: Make rational, safe and effective drug treatment decisions for therapy, evaluation and monitoring based on an integrated knowledge of therapeutics, medicinal chemistry, and pharmacology.
column38: Utilize an evidence-based approach to therapeutic management of the conditions of primary focus.
column39: Identify and locate sources of information needed to solve drug related problems.
column40: Critically evaluate the appropriateness and reliability of information from literature resources.
column41: Synthesize information gained from various literature resources to solve problems or make recommendations.
column42: Develop and practice skills for measuring blood pressure and heart rate.
column43: Utilize self-directed learning abilities.
column44: Work effectively in a healthcare team.
column45: Develop a caring, empathic attitude for patients experiencing the conditions of primary focus.
column46: Develop an appreciation of the interdisciplinary nature of patient care.
column47: Accept responsibility for keeping abreast of emerging technologies and drug

column18: The student will be able to describe the components of the healthcare system and how they interrelate as it pertains to the delivery of healthcare services in Canada and more specifically,Alberta.

column2: PHARM 382 Wi16 - PROV/CDN HEALTHCARE Combined LEC Wi16
column7: Health systems / Canadaâ€™s healthcare system / patient involvement
column14: Direct Lecture, Active Learning, Team Based Learning
column18: The student will be able to describe the components of the healthcare system and how they interrelate as it pertains to the delivery of healthcare services in Canada and more specifically,Alberta.
column19: The student will be able to list the names and describe the function of relevant health professional associations, government agencies, advocacy groups, and private sector players as it pertains to thedelivery of health care in Canada with particular emphasis on organizations that impact theprofession of pharmacy.
column20: The student will be able to describe some of the strategies that pharmacists and pharmacy organizations use to influence others within the Canadian healthcare system.
column21: The student will develop an appreciation for the recommendations made by current (i.e. within the past 10 years) studies, reports and reviews of the Canadian and Alberta health systems.

column2: PHARM 427 PAIN (LEC B1 Wi16)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column18: Describe the epidemiology, etiology, and risk factors of the conditions of primary focus.
column19: Describe the anatomy of central and peripheral nervous system as it relates to pain.
column20: Describe the physiology of central and peripheral nervous system as it relates to pain.
column21: Describe the pathophysiology of the conditions of primary focus.

column2: PHARM 427 PAIN (LEC B1 Wi16)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column18: Explain the effects of drugs used in the management of the conditions of primary focus.
column19: Describe the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of analgesics and antiinflammatory drugs.

column2: PHARM 427 PAIN (LEC B1 Wi16)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column18: Describe the principles of pharmacology relevant to the conditions of primary focus.
column19: Describe the pathophysiology of the conditions of primary focus.
column20: Explain the effects of drugs used in the management of the conditions of primary focus.
column21: Describe the therapeutic approach (Clinical Practice Guidelines) incorporating nonpharmacologic and pharmacologic treatments for the treatment and management of the conditions of primary focus including the use of specific target drugs for the condition as well as alternative therapies (dose, route of administration, duration of therapy, monitoring parameters for efficacy and toxicity).
column22: Describe and manage the toxicity of medications used in the management of the conditions of primary focus.
column23: Identify the role and the responsibility of the pharmacist within the course of the disease state and its therapy.
column24: Select and monitor drug therapy for the management of the conditions of primary focus by applying concepts and knowledge of medicinal chemistry, pharmacology and therapeutic principles.
column25: Identify the presenting signs and symptoms of the conditions of primary focus and describe criteria used to make the diagnosis and classify the severity of the disease.
column26: Recommend appropriate changes to therapy based on patient outcomes and monitoring parameters.
column27: Design pharmaceutical care plans including alternatives (drug, non-drug, referral, reassurance), recommendations, implementation, monitoring and follow up for patients with the conditions of primary focus.

column18: Demonstrate the ability to research and develop practical therapeutic knowledge for the management of several disease states.
column19: Demonstrate in-depth knowledge of a controversial topic, critical thinking skills, decision-making skills, and verbal communication skills.
column20: Demonstrate use of a therapeutic process to identify and prioritize actual and/or potential drug-related problems using a patient care centered approach.
column21: Answer a focused clinical question and create a patient care plan using a systematic problem-solving approach.
column22: Demonstrate refinement of critical appraisal, written and oral communication skills.
column23: Incorporate principles of evidence-based medicine into therapeutic decision making.
column24: Demonstrate a confident and competent approach to solving patient concerns.
column25: Utilize a seamless care approach to promote optimal patient outcomes in acute and chronic care settings.
column26: Apply appropriate documentation skills to facilitate care throughout a variety of settings.
column27: Demonstrate appropriate presentation skills (i.e. content, language) through case presentations.
column28: Demonstrate self-directed learning abilities and team skills.
column29: Accept responsibility of keeping current with emerging therapeutic modalities.

column2: PHARM 382 PROV/CDN HEALTHCARE (LEC B1 Wi17)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column14: Direct Lecture, Active Learning, Team Based Learning
column18: Describe the components of the healthcare system and how they interrelate as it pertains to the delivery of healthcare services in Canada and more specifically, Alberta.
column19: List the names and describe the function of relevant health professional associations, government agencies, advocacy groups, and private sector players as it pertains to the delivery of health care in Canada with particular emphasis on organizations that impact the profession of pharmacy.
column20: Describe some of the strategies that pharmacists and pharmacy organizations use to influence others within the Canadian healthcare system.
column21: Identify and debate key issues and challenges facing the Canadian healthcare system.
column22: Develop and debate solutions to some of the challenges facing the Canadian healthcare system with emphasis on how pharmacists and pharmacies can be a part of those solutions.
column23: Develop an appreciation for the recommendations made by current (i.e. within the past 10 years) studies, reports and reviews of the Canadian and Albertan health systems.
column24: Develop an appreciation of the different pharmacy service delivery models in different provincial and relevant international jurisdictions.

column2: PHARM 489 THERAP & PROF PRACT (SEM B1 Wi17)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column18: Demonstrate the ability to research and develop practical therapeutic knowledge for the management of several disease states.
column19: Demonstrate in-depth knowledge of a controversial topic, critical thinking skills, decision-making skills, and verbal communication skills.
column20: Demonstrate use of a therapeutic process to identify, prioritize, and resolve actual and/or potential drug-related problems using a patient care centered approach.
column21: Answer a focused clinical question and create a patient care plan using a systematic problem-solving approach.
column22: Demonstrate refinement of critical appraisal, written and oral communication skills.
column23: Incorporate principles of evidence-based medicine into therapeutic decision making.
column24: Demonstrate a confident and competent approach to solving patient concerns.
column25: Utilize a seamless care approach to promote optimal patient outcomes in acute and chronic care settings.
column26: Apply appropriate documentation skills to facilitate care throughout a variety of settings.
column27: Demonstrate appropriate presentation skills (i.e. content, language) through case presentations.
column28: Demonstrate self-directed learning abilities and team skills.
column29: Accept responsibility of keeping current with emerging therapeutic modalities.

column1: PHARM 397 (Fall 2017 LEC A1 A2 SEM E1 E2)
column2: PHARM 397 Fa17 - VALUES, UROLOGY & NEPHROLOGY Combined LEC SEM Fa17
column16: Physiology, Describe anatomy and function of the kidney, ureters, bladder and urethra, Describe physiology of the kidney, including regulation of glomerular filtration, sodium-water balance, fluid balance, acid-base balance as well as other electrolytes, tubular reabsorption and secretion., Describe physiology of the ureters, bladder and urethra including a general outline of bladder function and micturition

column2: PHARM 397 Fa17 - VALUES, UROLOGY & NEPHROLOGY Combined LEC SEM Fa17
column16: Drug Dosing in Renal Failure and Dialysis, Review of the assessment of renal function, including calculations of creatinine clearance and estimated GFR, Review the effects of renal impairment on the absorption, distribution, metabolism and excretion of drugs, Practical approach using case-based examples of adjusting medications in patients with renal impairment.

column1: PHARM 397 (Fall 2017 LEC A1 A2 SEM E1 E2)
column2: PHARM 397 Fa17 - VALUES, UROLOGY & NEPHROLOGY Combined LEC SEM Fa17
PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa17)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column16: RADIOSENSITIZATION AND PHOTOSENSITIZATION: Concepts and therapeutic advantage to combining radiation with pharmaceuticals; Mechanisms of radiation therapy and chemotherapy; The role of free radicals in mediating chemotherapeutic/toxic action; Chemical requirements for radiosensitizers; Radioprotection as a means to prevent damage to normal tissues; Photosensitization as a means to generate reactive species for photodynamic therapy

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa17)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column16: ADJUNCT AGENTS FOR USE WITH DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING: Specific examples where organ imaging requires enhancement with drugs; Mechanism of action of drugs and how the image improves

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa17)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column16: Summary of diagnostic imaging & contrast agents AND IN-CLASS QUIZ;X-RAY, ULTRASOUND, MRI: X-ray, ultrasound, MRI; Contrast agents (iodinated; bismuth) in Xray; Paramagnetic contrast agents in MRI; ultrasonic contrast agents.

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa17)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column16: RADIOPHARMACEUTICALS - PRACTICAL ASPECTS: Techniques for dispensing of radiopharmaceuticals; Tc99m generators

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa17)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column16: RADIOPHARMACEUTICALS - PRACTICAL ASPECTS: Design, calibration and use of equipment for radionuclide assays; Purpose of using radiopharmaceuticals, routes of administration, and safe dispensing.

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa17)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column16: RADIOPHARMACEUTICAL APPLICATIONS: Radiopharmaceuticals in clinical practice; Radiopharmaceuticals in bone scanning Radiopharmaceuticals in cardiology

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa17)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column16: POSITRON EMISSION TOMOGRAPHY (PET): Positron Emissions-Tomography (PET): Molecular imaging and molecular; Positron Emission Tomography (PET): A general introduction; PET-Radiotracers as molecular probes for medical research and clinical routin; PET-RADIOTRACERS AS MOLECULAR PROBES FOR MEDICAL RESEARCH AND CLINICAL ROUTIN

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa17)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column16: INTRODUCTION / RADIATION PRINCIPLES: Brief overview of what to expect from this course; Begin content of next lecture

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa17)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column16: RADIATION PRINCIPLES: Atomic structure; concepts of nuclear stability; radioactive isotopes; radiation emissions;Types of radioactive decay associated with nuclides commonly used for medical purposes.

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa17)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column16: Continuation of Radiation Principles and IN-CLASS QUIZ  (material so far)

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa17)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column16: RADIATION EFFECTS ON LIVING SYSTEMS; Units of radioactivity; calculations involving radioactive decay, calculations for radiopharmaceutical dosage to allow for radioactive decay; concepts of physical, biological and effective half-life; Charged particles; electromagnetic radiation, thermal and fast neurons, physical characteristics, sources, interactions with matter, energy loss, tissue penetration (this topic presented from a health sciences viewpoint)

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa17)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column16: RADIATION EFFECTS ON LIVING SYSTEMS: Concepts of radiation energy in terms of transfer and absorption in biological systems; Mechanisms of radiation induced injury; Oxidative stress as a result of radiation, and biological effects; Antioxidant enzymes as deterrents to free radical induced damage.

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa17)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column16: RADIATION EFFECTS ON LIVING SYSTEMS: Other radicals that can partake in radiation induced damage; Damage of free radicals to biological targets and its consequences; Free radicals and cell death; A description of the enzymatic and nonenzymatic systems to detoxify radiation induced free radical formation; Free radicals and cell death; Signalling mechanisms that can result in death or carcinogenesis

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa17)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column16: Know lectures 1-6 inclusive , MCQs based on material covered in week 1 - 3.

column2: PHARM 497 Wi18 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi18
column7: Course Introduction; Anatomy and Physiology (Part I)
column16: Negative feedback regulation, General function of the endocrine system, Overview of the endocrine glands

column2: PHARM 497 Wi18 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi18
column16: Glucose homeostasis, Introduction to dysfunction of endocrine system

column2: PHARM 497 Wi18 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi18
column16: Insulin biosynthesis and activation, Chemical features of different oral antidiabetic drugs

column2: PHARM 497 Wi18 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi18
column7: Introduction to Diabetes & Treatment of Type 1 Diabetes
column16: Discuss the practical management of insulin use with diet considerations (i.e. carbohydrates, Review insulin pumps and their role in Type 1 diabetes, as well as how to dose insulin accurately, Initiation and titration of insulin in the context of Type 1 diabetes, Review of insulin formulations, Treatment goals for diabetes, Risk factors for type 1 diabetes, Prevalence of diabetes, Definition and diagnostic criteria for prediabetes and diabetes

column2: PHARM 497 Wi18 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi18
column16: Highlight important differences between agents within the same pharmacologic class, Mechanisms of action for antidiabetic drugs

column2: PHARM 497 Wi18 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi18
column16: Describe treatment goals and pharmacologic options for patients with type 2 diabetes, Review pathophysiologic mechanisms contributing to development of type 2 diabetes, Describe the burden of diabetes and unmet needs

column2: PHARM 497 Wi18 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi18
column16: Describe treatment goals and pharmacologic options for patients with type 2 diabetes

column2: PHARM 497 Wi18 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi18
column7: Preparation time for Thyroid Case Discussions

column2: PHARM 497 Wi18 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi18
column7: Type 2 Diabetes Management Flowchart & Insulin Use in Type 2 Diabetes
column16: Discuss the role of concurrent use of insulin and antidiabetic drugs, Initiation and titration of insulin in the context of Type 2 diabetes, Review the Diabetes Canada treatment algorithm for type 2 diabetes

column2: PHARM 497 Wi18 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi18
column16: In groups of 5-6, students will work through two patient cases which will contain guided questions and varying scenarios covering common issues and themes related to insulin use and management (i.e. dosing, sick day management, hypoglycemia, travel). Groups will be randomly selected to present and discuss their answers to the cases., Students will engage in assigned pre-readings and review lecture material prior to the seminar.

column2: PHARM 497 Wi18 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi18
column7: Overview of Diabetes Management - Pragmatic Topics
column16: i.e. travel, storage, driving, acute illness management, Review practical considerations and patient education tips for patients living with diabetes

column2: PHARM 497 Wi18 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi18
column16: Strategies to manage gestational diabetes, Detection, risk factors, and prevention of gestational diabetes, Implications of gestational diabetes to the mother and baby

column2: PHARM 497 Wi18 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi18
column16: Outline management strategies for complications  the A-B-Cs of Diabetes Care, Describe important considerations of diabetes-related complications, Define the metabolic syndrome and what information this provides for patient management, Review key points from lifestyle intervention studies

column2: PHARM 497 Wi18 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi18
column16: In groups of 5-6, students will work up and discuss a series of mini-cases related to common issues with diabetes management. Each group will be responsible for presenting and leading a small discussion with the rest of the class on the case they were assigned to., Students will prepare a brief care plan (Type 2 diabetic patient) on a posted case to bring to seminar for discussion with their peers and facilitator. Risk factors and the patient care process will be discussed to identify drug-related problems and prepare an appropriate treatment plan for the patient., Students will engage in assigned pre-readings and review of lecture material prior to the seminar.

column2: PHARM 497 Wi18 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi18
column16: Describe point-of-care testing devices used for management of diabetes and its complications, Discuss current literature, evidence and considerations surrounding antidiabetic drugs, insulin and diabetes management

column2: PHARM 497 Wi18 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi18
column16: Introduction to secretion disorders (defining primary and secondary hyper- and hyposecretion), Endocrine function of the kidney, pineal gland, and heart, Endocrine function of the Hypothalamus-Pituitary-Adrenal axis

column2: PHARM 497 Wi18 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi18
column16: Recognize the main structural features of thyroid peroxidase enzyme inhibitors, Recognize the main structural features of thyroid hormones and analogs

column2: PHARM 497 Wi18 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi18
column16: Identify drugs which may interact with levothyroxine replacement, Provide appropriate counseling information, Develop a plan to monitor pharmacotherapy, Develop an appropriate patient-specific treatment plan, Describe the signs and symptoms, and goals of therapy, Identify drugs which may cause thyroid disease, Interpret laboratory tests in a patient diagnosed with hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism

column2: PHARM 497 Wi18 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi18
column16: Treatment options & strategies, Disorders of calcium homeostasis, Bone metabolism, Calcium physiology

column2: PHARM 497 Wi18 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi18
column7: Disorders of the Pituitary and Adrenals
column16: Adrenal gland disorders (pheochromocytoma, Cushings, Addisons), Pituitary gland disorders (hypersecretion & hyposecretion)

column2: PHARM 497 Wi18 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi18
column7: Complimentary & Alternative Medications for Diabetes & Thyroid
column16: Discuss the estimated prevalence of natural health products (NHP) use in diabetes, Discuss the role of the pharmacist in patient safety surrounding NHP use, Understand risks of drug interactions associated with NHPs, Discuss NHPs available for diabetes & thyroid disorders

column2: PHARM 497 Wi19 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi19
column16: Implications of gestational diabetes to the mother and baby, Detection, risk factors, and prevention of gestational diabetes, Strategies to manage gestational diabetes

column2: PHARM 497 Wi19 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi19
column7: Complimentary & Alternative Medications for Diabetes & Thyroid
column16: Discuss the estimated prevalence of natural health products (NHP) use in diabetes, Discuss NHPs available for diabetes & thyroid disorders, Understand risks of drug interactions associated with NHPs, Discuss the role of the pharmacist in patient safety surrounding NHP use

column2: PHARM 497 Wi19 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi19
column7: Disorders of the Pituitary and Adrenals
column16: Pituitary gland disorders (hypersecretion & hyposecretion), Adrenal gland disorders (pheochromocytoma, Cushings, Addisons)

column2: PHARM 497 Wi19 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi19
column16: Calcium physiology, Bone metabolism, Disorders of calcium homeostasis, Treatment options & strategies

column2: PHARM 497 Wi19 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi19
column16: Interpret laboratory tests in a patient diagnosed with hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism, Identify drugs which may cause thyroid disease, Describe the signs and symptoms, and goals of therapy, Develop an appropriate patient-specific treatment plan, Develop a plan to monitor pharmacotherapy, Provide appropriate counseling information, Identify drugs which may interact with levothyroxine replacement

column2: PHARM 497 Wi19 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi19
column16: Recognize the main structural features of thyroid hormones and analogs, Recognize the main structural features of thyroid peroxidase enzyme inhibitors

column2: PHARM 497 Wi19 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi19
column16: Endocrine function of the Hypothalamus-Pituitary-Adrenal axis, Endocrine function of the kidney, pineal gland, and heart, Introduction to secretion disorders (defining primary and secondary hyper- and hyposecretion)

column2: PHARM 497 Wi19 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi19
column16: Discuss current literature, evidence and considerations surrounding antidiabetic drugs, insulin and diabetes management, Describe point-of-care testing devices used for management of diabetes and its complications

column2: PHARM 497 Wi19 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi19
column16: Students will engage in assigned pre-readings and review of lecture material prior to the seminar., Students will prepare a brief care plan (Type 2 diabetic patient) on a posted case to bring to seminar for discussion with their peers and facilitator. Risk factors and the patient care process will be discussed to identify drug-related problems and prepare an appropriate treatment plan for the patient., In groups of 5-6, students will work up and discuss a series of mini-cases related to common issues with diabetes management. Each group will be responsible for presenting and leading a small discussion with the rest of the class on the case they were assigned to.

column2: PHARM 497 Wi19 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi19
column16: Review key points from lifestyle intervention studies, Define the metabolic syndrome and what information this provides for patient management, Describe important considerations of diabetes-related complications, Outline management strategies for complications  the A-B-Cs of Diabetes Care

column2: PHARM 497 Wi19 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi19
column16: Students will engage in assigned pre-readings and review lecture material prior to the seminar., In groups of 5-6, students will work through two patient cases which will contain guided questions and varying scenarios covering common issues and themes related to insulin use and management (i.e. dosing, sick day management, hypoglycemia, travel). Groups will be randomly selected to present and discuss their answers to the cases.

column2: PHARM 497 Wi19 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi19
column7: Overview of Diabetes Management - Pragmatic Topics
column16: Review practical considerations and patient education tips for patients living with diabetes, i.e. travel, storage, driving, acute illness management

column2: PHARM 497 Wi19 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi19
column7: Type 2 Diabetes Management Flowchart & Insulin Use in Type 2 Diabetes
column16: Review the Diabetes Canada treatment algorithm for type 2 diabetes, Initiation and titration of insulin in the context of Type 2 diabetes, Discuss the role of concurrent use of insulin and antidiabetic drugs

column2: PHARM 497 Wi19 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi19
column7: Preparation time for Thyroid Case Discussions

column2: PHARM 497 Wi19 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi19
column16: Describe treatment goals and pharmacologic options for patients with type 2 diabetes

column2: PHARM 497 Wi19 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi19
column16: Describe the burden of diabetes and unmet needs, Review pathophysiologic mechanisms contributing to development of type 2 diabetes, Describe treatment goals and pharmacologic options for patients with type 2 diabetes

column2: PHARM 497 Wi19 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi19
column16: Mechanisms of action for antidiabetic drugs, Highlight important differences between agents within the same pharmacologic class

column2: PHARM 497 Wi19 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi19
column7: Introduction to Diabetes & Treatment of Type 1 Diabetes
column16: Definition and diagnostic criteria for prediabetes and diabetes, Prevalence of diabetes, Risk factors for type 1 diabetes, Treatment goals for diabetes, Review of insulin formulations, Initiation and titration of insulin in the context of Type 1 diabetes

column2: PHARM 497 Wi19 - ENDOCRINE Combined LEC SEM Wi19

column16: disease clasification, epidemiology, etiology, pathophysiology, clinical presentation, prognosis, diagnosis, patient assessment, goals of therapy, approach to treatment, clinical trial evidence, DMARDs - conventional synthetic
column17: "Explain the basic pathophysiology of RA", "Describe the clinical presentation, diagnostic criteria, and monitoring tools utilized for RA", "Describe the approach to the treatment of RA and the role of the various medications used to achieve the goals of therapy", "Consider the 4 Pillars: Indication, Efficacy, Safety, Cost/Compliance"
column18: Outline the epidemiology, etiology and pathophysiology of the reproductive & sexual health and musculoskeletal/joint conditions covered.
column19: Describe the risk factors, clinical presentation, and assessment parameters (signs and symptoms, laboratory values/tests, physical findings and diagnostic measurements) of the conditions covered.
column20: Explain the mechanism of action, pharmacokinetic principles, clinical effect(s), adverse effects & drug interactions for the medication classes covered.
column21: Describe the therapeutic approach to managing the conditions covered, including:
column22: a. guideline recommendations and clinical targets,
column23: b. pharmacological (dose, duration of therapy, monitoring parameters),
column24: Conduct a patient assessment using relevant data from the patient history, review of systems, laboratory tests, diagnostic imaging and drug therapy in order to provide patient care.
column25: Utilize independent and collaborative approaches to learning.
column26: Develop a caring, empathic attitude for patients experiencing the conditions covered.
column27: Appreciate the need for lifelong learning skills that will enable maintenance of competence through keeping abreast of emerging technologies and drugs.

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa18)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column16: INTRODUCTION / RADIATION PRINCIPLES: Brief overview of what to expect from this course; Begin content of next lecture
column18: This module has been designed to familiarize pharmacy students with basic principles of diagnostic imaging, with emphasis on the use of radiation and radioactive drugs and contrast agents in medical diagnosis and therapy. The biological effects of radiation are presented from the viewpoint of a pharmacist's perspective as a health sciences team member.

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa18)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column16: RADIATION PRINCIPLES: Atomic structure; concepts of nuclear stability; radioactive isotopes; radiation emissions;Types of radioactive decay associated with nuclides commonly used for medical purposes.
column18: This module has been designed to familiarize pharmacy students with basic principles of diagnostic imaging, with emphasis on the use of radiation and radioactive drugs and contrast agents in medical diagnosis and therapy. The biological effects of radiation are presented from the viewpoint of a pharmacist's perspective as a health sciences team member.

column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

column18: This module has been designed to familiarize pharmacy students with basic principles of diagnostic imaging, with emphasis on the use of radiation and radioactive drugs and contrast agents in medical diagnosis and therapy. The biological effects of radiation are presented from the viewpoint of a pharmacist's perspective as a health sciences team member.
column19: To consider the various types of radiation and their characteristics and interactions with matter from the viewpoint of how these factors: Influence the utility of different radiations for clinical diagnosis or for therapy; Can present a health hazard from improper use or handling; Determine the methods of radiation detection and measurement

column2: PHARM 311 RADIOPHARM/DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING (LEC A1 Fa18)
column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column16: RADIATION EFFECTS ON LIVING SYSTEMS; Units of radioactivity; calculations involving radioactive decay, calculations for radiopharmaceutical dosage to allow for radioactive decay; concepts of physical, biological and effective half-life; Charged particles; electromagnetic radiation, thermal and fast neurons, physical characteristics, sources, interactions with matter, energy loss, tissue penetration (this topic presented from a health sciences viewpoint)
column18: To consider the various types of radiation and their characteristics and interactions with matter from the viewpoint of how these factors: Influence the utility of different radiations for clinical diagnosis or for therapy; Can present a health hazard from improper use or handling; Determine the methods of radiation detection and measurement

column3: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
column16: RADIATION EFFECTS ON LIVING SYSTEMS: Concepts of radiation energy in terms of transfer and absorption in biological systems; Mechanisms of radiation induced injury; Oxidative stress as a result of radiation, and biological effects; Antioxidant enzymes as deterrents to free radical induced damage.
column18: To consider the various types of radiation and their characteristics and interactions with matter from the viewpoint of how these factors: Influence the utility of different radiations for clinical diagnosis or for therapy; Can present a health hazard from improper use or handling; Determine the methods of radiation detection and measurement

column18: To consider the various types of radiation and their characteristics and interactions with matter from the viewpoint of how these factors: Influence the utility of different radiations for clinical diagnosis or for therapy; Can present a health hazard from improper use or handling; Determine the methods of radiation detection and measurement
